question: Do you know what she told me last night?
answer: A man's worth can be judged by what he has or what he owes. Only the amount matters.

question: And bankruptcy. Where will that put me in the social strata?
answer: I'm only asking for one thing. And it's not an extravagance. It's not even for me; it's for our daughter.

question: Our daughter.
answer: Our child's safety is at stake.

question: These people are professionals. They don't waste their time taking children whose fathers are virtually bankrupt.
answer: Samuel, it is not something we should skimp on. A bodyguard's presence in the car or outside the school was at least some form of deterrent. Now he's gone, I feel totally exposed.

question: Of course I care about Pinta. She'll be as beautiful as her mother one day.
answer: Yeah? And if she was ugly? All my clients have kidnap and ransom insurance.

question: I have a policy, AIG. It covers me and my family and when it runs out in sixty days, without a bodyguard, I will not be able to renew it.
answer: I know you need to please Lisa. An ass like that is hard to find. Good bodyguards are even harder.

question: I know! I just had to let one go because I couldn't afford him!
answer: You need a bodyguard of some description. It's a dangerous world we live in. But you will get what you pay for. He doesn't need to be Superman, does he? Can you go fifteen grand?

question: For a year?
answer: For a few months. Hire someone cheap. You have to have a bodyguard to keep the insurance. Then fire him for incompetence. The important thing is Lisa's daughter will return to school.

question: And Lisa will be able to save face. We won't be the only family without a bodyguard.
answer: Her beauty fucks with your mind.

question: For an American she understands this country very well.
answer: She understands men.

question: Where are you coming from?
answer: South America.

question: Where are you staying in Mexico?
answer: I'm on to Juarez.

question: Why?
answer: I have a friend there.

question: I cannot see your eyes, Senor. Senor?
answer: It's a permit to carry a gun in Columbia. The gun you're about to find in that suitcase.

question: It's a permit to carry a gun in Columbia. The gun you're about to find in that suitcase.
answer: Rayburn here.

question: When did Mexican Customs start getting smart?
answer: Creasy??? Where the fuck are you?

question: I'm here.
answer: What do you mean, I'm here?

question: I'm in a Customs holding tank in Mexico City International. Bring a bunch of cash... about 5K. I'm going to need it.
answer: This is going to cost you big time. You got a secondary search and you had a gun.

question: Listen it was a calculated risk. I've done it a million times and never got caught.
answer: Everything happens once if you live long enough.

question: It doesn't make sense to x-ray your bags coming off the plane.
answer: This is Mexico, they do everything backwards. So what's wrong?

question: Nothing wrong.
answer: Don't give me that bullshit.

question: So how's business?
answer: Japanese are here in a big way. Cheap labor. Factory space. But they feel a lot safer living over the border in El Paso. I ferry 'em back and forth. They think I'm John-fucking-Wayne.

question: But don't you stay in El Paso?
answer: Fuck, I love Mexico. I live like a king down here.

question: Yeah, right...
answer: Oh, like you haven't been in worse places.

question: And a level five shithole is better than a level six. Your logic's inescapable.
answer: You been working?

question: Not for eight months. I was in Columbia looking around, but, nothing seemed interesting.
answer: How long you staying, Crease?

question: Got no plans, Rayburn, Nothing on. Just wanted to see you, how you were. Came by on impulse.
answer: You did something on impulse?

question: Dear God. I do not ask for health. Or wealth. People ask you so often that you can't have any left. Give me God what you still have. Give me what no one else asks for. Amen.
answer: You should be sleeping, baby.

question: I'm trying, mom.
answer: Good news. You're going back to school.

question: When?
answer: Samuel is going to hire a new bodyguard. It may take a few days, but you're going back.

question: Could he speak English? Emilio couldn't speak English.
answer: We'll see. And thank your father in the morning. A man always needs to be thanked.

question: That's right, a bodyguard. Your Spanish is good enough. You certainly look the part.
answer: You're crazy. People would hire a has- been, Ray? A drunk?

question: Well, you'd have to keep it under control.
answer: And what if, just say, there was a kidnap attempt?

question: You do your best. They won't be paying you enough to perform miracles. It's not exactly a scam, Crease. Even at half speed you're pretty damn good.
answer: A bodyguard has to be close to someone all the time. Willing to talk. I'm not good at that.

question: So you'll be the silent type. People will appreciate that. What are you doing here?
answer: I came to visit you.

question: Bullshit. I've known you fifteen years. You don't visit.
answer: A bodyguard... Who's the guy?

question: Samuel Ramos. Owns one of the plants in Juarez. The Jap car industry is in the toilet. He's trying to persuade Ford to partner with him. I think he's in trouble. He asked me if I knew anyone he could trust.
answer: Oh, now you think I can be trusted.

question: You drive easily. Smoothly. Were you provided with a gun?
answer: Yes.

question: Show me, please. What is it?
answer: Nine millimeter. A Sig Sauer 226.

question: Have you used this type before? Is it loaded?
answer: It's loaded.

question: You will meet my wife first. She would like it if you are presentable, polite and respectful. You'll be the fifth candidate she's seen this week. Your resume is impressive. Nine years in the Army. Extensive counter terrorism work. I shouldn't be able to afford you in my current state. What's the catch?
answer: I drink.

question: How does it affect you?
answer: My coordination. Reaction time. If top professionals try to kidnap your daughter, the service will be on par with the pay.

question: And what if amateurs try it?
answer: I'll probably kill them. Is that likely?

question: Pinta!
answer: Yes, mom?

question: This is Mr. Creasy. Pinta, show him to his room.
answer: This way, Mr. Creasy.

question: Do you like dogs, Mr. Creasy?
answer: If they like me.

question: Frank doesn't take to most people. Do you speak German?
answer: Ein Klines Bisschen.

question: Frank only responds to commands in German. He was trained in Frankfurt. My Dad loves the idea of having a dog around, but hates the fact he lives inside. We fixed the room up two weeks ago. Mom and I. It's nicer than before. You've got a CD player if you like music. I like music a lot. That's 'Bird.' Emilio forgot to take him with when he left.
answer: Who's Emilio?

question: My last bodyguard. He drove me to school in the morning and picked me up in the afternoon.
answer: I'm here for you?

question: In between you can take Mom shopping and to lunch. Does that sound alright, Mr. Creasy?
answer: Creasy. Just call me Creasy.

question: Creasy... Looks like he approves of you.
answer: School tomorrow, baby.

question: I like him, Mom.
answer: You do?

question: He's like a great big bear. 'Creasy bear'... There's something about him. I think he's been sick. He's alright now, but I think he's been very, very sick.
answer: Well, think about going to sleep. Good night, baby.

question: Where are you from, Creasy?
answer: The United States.

question: I know. But which state?
answer: No state in particular.

question: My mom and me are from Houston, Texas. Have you been there?
answer: No.

question: You can drive and talk at the same time, can't you?
answer: No.

question: Why not?
answer: I'm looking for potential.

question: Potential? I don't understand.
answer: Places where the road bends, places away from buildings, places where the traffic thins out. But you don't have to understand. I do. So no talking.

question: Are you going to quit? My last bodyguard quit.
answer: Let me guess, you wouldn't stop talking?

question: Someone gave him more money than we could.
answer: I'm a bargain.

question: Being black, is that a positive or negative for a bodyguard in Mexico?
answer: Time will tell.

question: There were 24 kidnappings in Mexico City in the last six days. Four a day. What do you think about that, Mr. Creasy?
answer: Pretty impressive. Maybe I need to up my fee or get a larger gun.

question: You must look after our Pinta. We're so happy to have her back in school. Run along now, Pinta. She's late, Mr. Creasy.
answer: Yeah, I've got to get used to the routes. I -- It won't happen again.

question: No offense, but I'm sorry that your profession needs to exist.
answer: So am I, Sister.

question: Do you ever see the hand of God in what you do?
answer: Not for a long time, sister.

question: The bible says, "Be not overcome of evil, but overcome evil with good."
answer: Romans, chapter 12, verse 21. I'm the sheep that got lost. Here we go again. Yeah. And Spanish. It's a temporary license for the gun I'm carrying. I just went through all of this at the airport.

question: We're taking a different way home.
answer: That's right.

question: I understand. Smart. Did you like school, Creasy?
answer: No.

question: Not at all?
answer: No.

question: But why not? Hmmm?
answer: It wasn't a school like yours and there was no Sister Anna.

question: So you were unhappy?
answer: Being unhappy is a state of mind. I never thought about it.

question: Oh... What happened to... ...your hand?
answer: No more questions. I'm not paid to be your friend. I'm paid to protect you. And don't start crying.

question: I'm not crying.
answer: Look, this is the way I am. I don't like questions. I -- Shit.

question: You can take me home now, Mr. Creasy.
answer: Come in.

question: Come in.
answer: Mr. Creasy, I wanted to make sure you have everything you need.

question: I'm fine.
answer: Is the food alright? Maria tells me that you didn't eat.

question: The food's fine. Sometimes I don't eat.
answer: It insults Maria. Slip it to the dog if you have to... Do you mind if I talk to you for a moment? How are you getting along with Pinta?

question: We'll be okay once she realizes I'm not a new toy.
answer: Yes, she told me. Do you have children, Mr. Creasy?

question: No.
answer: You should know they're tenacious when they want something. And Pinta wants to be friends.

question: You're paying me to protect her, not amuse her. Right? Look. Maybe this isn't going to work. Maybe you should ask your husband to hire someone... more sociable.
answer: No, you're right. You were hired to protect her, that's enough. I'm confident you'll do that. I didn't realize you had a gun. I know that's silly to say. It makes it all seem so serious.

question: It is serious, Mrs. Ramos.
answer: Please, it's Lisa... I'll be coming with you tomorrow. I have lunch with friends.

question: Rayburn... Creasy! What's wrong?
answer: I said, have you ever had a nine millimeter round that just didn't go off?

question: You mean a misfire?
answer: I mean nothing. The hammer came down and nothing happened. Dimple on the primer.

question: I've heard of it. Never happened to me though. Maybe the firing pin's off.
answer: Maybe...

question: It's like we always used to say Creasy?
answer: Sorry I woke you, Ray.

question: Hey... Pinta... What are you doing?
answer: Calling for Emilio's macaw. I thought I heard him.

question: Do you think he'll come back?
answer: Maybe. Did you hear him?

question: No.
answer: How do you think he got out?

question: Well, I let him go.
answer: It's better to be free, right?

question: Yes. Actually, he was driving me crazy.
answer: I got you to talk, Creasy bear.

question: They'll be back in a week.
answer: They can stay for two weeks. I don't care.

question: The food is excellent, Maria. You have a real talent.
answer: Come on. Come on. Bird!

question: Pinta!
answer: It hurts.

question: Where?
answer: Everywhere!

question: I don't think they're broken. Anywhere else?
answer: My ankle.

question: I'm going to get you out, okay?
answer: Oh, Creasy...

question: The night you arrived, Mom asked you if you had a family and you lied, didn't you?
answer: White lie. I didn't have a family. But I did have two kids. They're adults now. Do you always sleep with him?

question: I'm too old for him. Don't tell my friends.
answer: I don't talk to them much. Does he have a name? I spoke to your mother. She sends her love. Some bodyguard I turned out to be. Good night, Pinta.

question: Creasy? Could you play the song?
answer: Blue Bayou. You got it.

question: I think I'll sit in the front. There's more room for my foot. He's only allowed to travel in the car on weekends. Dad says the car will smell 'doggie'.
answer: Did you sleep alright?

question: Yes.
answer: How's the ankle? Can you put your weight on it?

question: It's not too bad. Will it take a long time before it's better? Our big swim meet is in three weeks. Interschools. I was going to swim in the one hundred meter freestyle.
answer: In a week you should be fine.

question: Doesn't matter. I always finish second.
answer: You need to practice.

question: I will. Creasy, what's a concubine?
answer: Why do you ask?

question: It was in a book at school. Concubine.
answer: Well, it's a sort of wife.

question: But the Emperor of China had 1000 of them! How can that be?
answer: In the West, it's one wife for one husband, but different cultures have different rules.

question: It must be difficult having lots of wives.
answer: You feel sorry for the husband?

question: Yeah. Can you imagine my mother multiplied by a thousand? Creasy, you're smiling.
answer: I guess I am.

question: So how come you know so much about those countries?
answer: I had to do my homework on them when I worked there. Also I enjoy history.

question: What did you do in Asia? Is that where you met the man with cigarettes?
answer: No, that was in Columbia. Bang! No, no, come back. You don't flinch when a gun goes off; you react. You go. Don't listen for the sound; don't anticipate it. Concentrate on the sound itself.

question: I don't understand.
answer: Don't worry. You will.

question: Creasy, what happened to your hand?
answer: A man asked me questions once. He smoked a lot. There was no ashtray. Remember you asked me what state I was from?

question: Yes.
answer: Where you're from isn't so much about geography; it's about events. Where you're from is what happened to you.

question: Good things happen, too, Creasy. Like meeting me.
answer: I guess that really does make me a hard case.

question: Do you have a girlfriend, Creasy?
answer: No.

question: Did you used to?
answer: Yeah. Two or three.

question: Yeah. Two or three.
answer: Creasy, tomorrow, after you drop off Pinta, could you come back to take me to get my hair done? Alright, I'll leave you two to your history.

question: Don't move.
answer: Murdering people in the street... You had your gun, why didn't you shoot them?

question: Nothing to do with me. Or you. Besides, there was another one in the passenger side of the van with a sawed-off shotgun. If I'd started shooting his friends, he would've had me. And you. A minimum close protection team consists of four men for high threat targets and environments. Even in a low threat situation, you need two guards plus a security trained driver.
answer: You're late.

question: I'm sorry.
answer: You were never late before, I was worried. Where's my mother?

question: I dropped her at home.
answer: It's no wonder you're late. Why didn't she just come with you? Do you think my mother likes you?

question: I think she's afraid of me. But not the same way most people are.
answer: I'm not afraid you, Creasy.

question: I know you're not.
answer: Are you afraid of me?

question: I used to be. At first. But not anymore.
answer: Good.

question: The gunshot holds no fear. Say it.
answer: The gunshot holds no fear.

question: You welcome the sound. The sound is what lets you go. The sound is what frees you. You are a prisoner in those blocks until you hear the sound.
answer: I'm tough, Creasy. I'm tough as you.

question: There's no such thing as tough. You're either trained or untrained. Sleeping, looking sexy.
answer: Hi, Dad.

question: What's so important in Los Angeles?
answer: Your father has business.

question: Why today? And why'd she have to go with him?
answer: Good luck. I'll be waiting here when you're done.

question: You're coming with me. Stand near the finish line.
answer: Pinta. The blocks.

question: Could I ask you a question?
answer: Could I stop you?

question: You don't drink like you used to.
answer: That's not a question.

question: I know because I go in your room and check the bottles.
answer: Still not a question.

question: My mom drinks, too... Why do people drink, Creasy?
answer: Now that's a question. I don't know about your Mom. For me, the problem isn't in the glass. The problem's in between my ears.

question: You think too much?
answer: Yeah. Because at one time, I didn't think enough.

question: He has to go, Samuel.
answer: What? Who?

question: Creasy.
answer: Why? You were so pleased with him.

question: Pinta likes him too much. She thinks of him as a father.
answer: That's ridiculous.

question: It's not.
answer: I've just been so busy, Lisa.

question: He has to go.
answer: The three month trial ends in a week. I just won't confirm the position. That possibility was understood when I hired him. I won't create bad feelings. And another week won't make a difference. It will be a hard break.

question: She's young. She'll get over it.
answer: I wasn't thinking of Pinta. Creasy, how are you?

question: Frank. Frankie.
answer: Pinta, we've got to go. Travel sucks at this time.

question: Frank. Frankie.
answer: That's strange. Frank was a no-show. Not like him to miss a ride.

question: You should break all my fingers, Creasy, then tape them back together. I won't be able to play the piano, but I could still swim.
answer: Don't be a baby. You're tougher than that.

question: There's no such thing as tough, Creasy. Just trained and untrained.
answer: Then be trained.

question: I'm going to keep people safe someday. Just like you.
answer: Be a swimmer.

question: I could do it. Remember the day you wanted the pencil? I know why. And I saw that car again. I wrote the license number in my notebook. Except I missed the last number.
answer: You'll have to show me that number when we get home. Continue to play in the wrong key, like you're dyslexic.

question: Dyslexic?
answer: Like St. Jude. A hopeless case that has a complete block about 'C' Minor. But remember, "Whoever resists authority will bring judgement upon themselves." New Testament, Romans 13.

question: You got that right.
answer: You'll be back in the water in twenty- four hours.

question: For you, Creasy.
answer: Remember 'dyslexic.' Looking up from the window of the Mercedes. As Pinta is called back inside, Creasy checks out, twirls the dandelion Pinta gave him. HUMS to himself. "Blue Bayou." Run, Pinta, run!

question: Creasy... Creasy!
answer: Pinta... Don't die, Creasy, don't die.

question: That's good. Really good. He shot and killed two judicial cops and a kidnapper died in the attack. They're saying he's responsible.
answer: We're looking into it.

question: The two officers who were killed. Records show they were off duty at the time.
answer: I'm not sure. All I know is they died bravely.

question: If they were off duty, why were they in a patrol car? What exactly were they doing at the scene of a kidnapping? Were they known for their exceptional good luck?
answer: They were known for their professionalism and integrity!

question: I'm here to see my friend.
answer: When I heard it was this hospital I was so pleased. There's a pastry shop nearby. Delgado's. Do you know it? The best pastries in Mexico. Miguel Manzano.

question: He's not a cop killer.
answer: I'm sure he isn't. Though he's certainly adept at killing.

question: He was doing his job, protecting the girl. If police were involved, you figure it out. I'm here for him.
answer: So am I.

question: You have the money.
answer: Yes.

question: OK,repeat the drop instructions.
answer: The money, 10 million U.S. will be divided into two 15 gallon black canvas bags each containing five million which will be checked at the bank by the K&R agent. Then driven to the house in an armored car where it will be transferred to the delivery car.

question: The car will not be powerful and have no trunk.
answer: I need a driver to drive Samuel, the father.

question: No. Why?
answer: He has a heart condition. Angina. He responds badly to stress.

question: OK. You will arrive at Columbus Circle and Reforma Avenue at 3AM. You will drive around the square two times. Samuel will remove his shirt and hold it out the window to I.D. the car. There is a payphone on the Southeast corner. The phone will ring. You will answer and wait for instruction.
answer: We need proof of life.

question: She's dead. They fucked with 'the process' and his nephew died. Did he say so? Nothing? Excellent work by the way. Three men dead. Only ten rounds fired. If two of the men in my division could shoot like that, I could get rid of the other thirty-six.
answer: What am I doing here?

question: Believe it or not, you're safe here. The Judicial police will kill you. If they can. This page?
answer: No.

question: You have a rather checkered past. Mr. Creasy. Your Interpol file is six pages long.
answer: Am I a suspect?

question: No. It would be convenient, but no.
answer: Show me mugshots of Mexican policemen. Maybe then we'll get somewhere.

question: Got a thing I gotta do first. Corolla. Muzzle flashes. Pinta screaming...
answer: A lot of people are looking for you.

question: I guess that makes you the smart one.
answer: We're interested in the same thing. I'm writing a story. This might interest you. I found it across the street. It's Santa Muerte. Death worship. The religion of La Hermanidad. There's a curse on you.

question: It's a little late.
answer: What are you going to do? I can help. I have a situation Mr. Creasy. There is a brotherhood called Le Hermanidad which protects both high ranking Government officials, corrupt police, and organized crime at a level that is very difficult for me to touch. I believe you were a victim of this organization. You and this story may help to unmask them.

question: Thank you.
answer: You let them take her. She loved you and you let them take her. Why are you here? Why didn't you die?

question: Because... I was already dead. I want you to know something. I'm going to kill them. Anyone who opens their eyes at me.
answer: Creasy... Kill them, Creasy. Kill them all.

question: Blue Bayou is a dream, Pinta. Like you. Why are you here?
answer: You'll be Stateside by suppertime.

question: I'm going to need help, Ray.
answer: Fuck. Look at you; you won't last a day the shape you're in. Unless you stop bleeding you should have your spleen removed.

question: Yes or no?
answer: I won't kill again. Hunt people. I gave that up. Anything else? It's yours. Jesus, Creasy. You're talking war. Candy store. Every town in Mexico has one if you know what door to bang on.

question: I'll take the .45 and the Webley .32.
answer: I know it's old fashioned, but it's reliable. Like us.

question: I need less than standard packing. Can you knock up a case for fifteen of each? Cut the stock here. The barrel here. Make sure you file it smooth. Rocket launchers?
answer: Different door. Not far from here.

question: Maybe I can help your situation and you mine.
answer: So where do we begin?

question: I need the name and address of the owner of a Toyota Corolla, license number ME31704...We didn't get the last digit so I need the ten possible matches.
answer: So what do I get in return?

question: Can you hear me? I am going to ask questions. If you don't answer, fully and truthfully, you will suffer much more than you have to. I'm going to cut your fingers off. One by one. If I have to. That's to cauterize the stubs.
answer: Do you know who I am?

question: Who are you?
answer: I am the President of La Hermanidad. Stares at the stump of his right forefinger, smoke rising up off it. Creasy sticks the lighter back in its hole. Wh- wh- what do you want to know?

question: The Ramos kidnapping. How did it work?
answer: I don't know. We were just given instructions to take her.

question: Ordered by who?
answer: I don't know. I don't know! We work in parts. A voice calls in a kidnapping. We deliver the target to the guardians. We don't even know them. They might transfer to other guardians. The negotiators and the bosses don't even see the target. They just make the deal!

question: Who ordered it?
answer: The cops call him 'The Dreamer'.

question: Where do I find him?
answer: I don't know. No one knows. I don't know, I swear.

question: I believe you.
answer: I'm professional. I just do my job.

question: Me, too. Tell me about the guardians.
answer: He called me on the cell phone to set a time and location for the switch.

question: Who's he?
answer: The one who transferred Pinta to their car.

question: Who's he?
answer: I don't know, but I know his face. I see him sometimes at the handball court in Chapultepec on a Saturday afternoon.

question: How do I recognize him.
answer: He has a tattoo covering two-thirds of his back. He is part of the Brotherhood.

question: In the next hour, where do I find your partner?
answer: One-one-three Arco Iris. Third floor.

question: Hola!
answer: Tell me about the girl. How does it work?

question: Everything on the cellphone. We wait for calls. We have no number to call.
answer: Who pays you?

question: We have an ATM bank card. We draw out 300 dollars every two weeks.
answer: What's the PIN number?

question: The what?
answer: The number you use at the bank machine.

question: Four-seven-four-seven.
answer: Who killed her? You?

question: No!
answer: Don't lie to me.

question: The boss did or his brother.
answer: Who's the boss?

question: We don't know! We never see his face! We have to wait in the other room. He was screaming to the girl that... ...his nephew was killed in the exchange. And the money was stolen.
answer: What money?

question: The ransom money. At the drop. He said Tazinari, one of the policemen had taken it. He was crazy.
answer: Who's Tazinari?

question: Head of the antikidnapping division.
answer: Show me. Who? Who's they? Now listen to me. If you tell me where to find the boss. I will let you live.

question: Roman chapter 13:7. Therefore whoever resists authority will bring judgement on themselves. Now it is time to awake out of sleep for our salvation is nearer than we first believed.
answer: Rosanna Guerrero.

question: It's Creasy.
answer: Where are you?

question: Los Arcos. Was a little girl kidnapped recently? About twelve maybe?
answer: Last night. Do you know something?

question: What was her name?
answer: Camila. Camila Valencias.

question: Camila. Camila Valencias.
answer: Camila. I've got her. I need something. Do you have banking connections?

question: I have connections.
answer: The PIN number is 4-7-4-7. I need to know whose account it is.

question: Where do I find you?
answer: I'll call you tomorrow. What do you know about the cop? Tazinari. The one who made the ransom drop with Samuel Ramos?

question: He's an old fashioned patrone with the worst reputation. He's high on my hit list.
answer: Where does he live?

question: He lives in a Judicial Compound. He travels by motorcade. He has better protection than George Bush. Even more importantly he is part of La Hermanidad. His reach is far and wide.
answer: Give me the address.

question: Whoever did this was methodical, unafraid. Was Jorge's mugshot in the photos we showed Creasy? Mr. Creasy was, and maybe is again, a very lethal human being. What's surprising these days? Your sister? Only a virgin cooks like this. Pollo Pibil. Chicken and chorizo sausage. Hmmmh. They marinate it in lemon and orange juice. It's a stew really.
answer: I already ate.

question: Tell me about your friend Creasy.
answer: You just said it. He's my friend. Nothing else to say.

question: I read the file. You and Creasy have seen quite a bit together.
answer: Two tourists who never went home.

question: You helped him get this job.
answer: That's what friends do.

question: Yes. But if I traced Creasy to you, others will do it as well. Their facilities are as good as my own, if not better.
answer: I can take care of myself.

question: You and Creasy both. A two man army according to Interpol. Panama. Lebanon with the Druze. Desert Storm. Where you were contracted by the U.S. Army to hunt down elite Iraqi military commanders. You two were a married couple.
answer: The kind that gets divorced, but still stay friends.

question: What happened to him? What happened to Creasy?
answer: None of your business. Or mine for that matter. I got nothing more to say.

question: This is my jurisdiction. I want these men as much as Creasy does.
answer: He'll deliver more justice in a weekend, than ten years of your courts and tribunals. So stay out of his way.

question: I plan to. I'll even help him if I can. He's going to lead me to the 'The Dreamer'. Someone I want very badly. But I'd like to understand him. Give me that.
answer: Pinta Martin Ramos is just a number to you. Tragic, a public outcry, but a number. One more dead.

question: What was she to Creasy then?
answer: Light. At the end of a long, dark tunnel. Somehow, she showed him it was alright to live again.

question: And they took that away.
answer: A man can be an artist in anything. Stone, paint, words. Food. Anything if his soul is true to it. Creasy's art is death. And he's about to paint his masterpiece. Me? I got Jap businessmen to drive across the border. So, if you'll do me a favor and let me the fuck out of here...

question: Is it true? Creasy saved the little girl that was kidnapped yesterday.
answer: And left three more dead men.

question: When you talked to him, did he look sane?
answer: No. Not by the rules of polite society at least.

question: I think he's... magnificent. You only fuck me to get information.
answer: You only give information so you can fuck me.

question: A beautiful circle.
answer: Let's put Creasy to press. There's a vigilante cleaning up Mexico. An unstoppable hero. And as long as we're talking information, there's something else as well.

question: I'm not here to hurt you. I need to borrow your house and your car. Are you the proud owners of the Coupe deVille? If you promise to speak softly and not to shout, I won't have to tape your mouths. Did you know you have a dishonest policeman living in your neighborhood? Forgiveness is between them and God. It's my job to arrange the meeting. Do you have an old blanket you don't care about? I don't want to burn that wall. A 'Man On Fire' strides through the smoke and dust. A shotgun at his side and a Molotov cocktail in his left hand. You know where you are? Under the bridge. Where the deal went south. Now why don't you tell me what went down?
answer: Do you know who I am? I am the commandante of the Judicial anti- kidnapping division.

question: And one of the founding members of La Hermanidad.
answer: Correct!

question: That's not my dick. That's the barrel of your own gun. Shoved up your own ass. .44 Magnum. Now, how's your hearing?
answer: Please, don't...

question: It's all up to you, commandante. Tell me about you and 'The Dreamer'.
answer: I don't know him. I saw the opportunity and got lucky.

question: Lucky how?
answer: That he used policemen. That you killed them, it made it a police matter. The Ramos family couldn't refuse our involvement.

question: And?
answer: And I had my men ready.

question: You stole the drop. You done it before?
answer: Yes. Many times.

question: O.K. So tell me more.
answer: There was no ten million dollars.

question: The ransom was ten.
answer: Two and a half. That's how much there was.

question: Don't lie to me!
answer: Two and a half! The rest was paper! Strips of paper!

question: Maybe your men stole from you.
answer: No. Whoever took the rest took it before the exchange.

question: Who gave the bags to Ramos?
answer: His lawyer. Jordan Kalfus. That's all I know! Please. I'm sorry for the girl. But it was business! I'm a professional.

question: A bullet does not lie. A bullet tells the truth. And the truth will set you free. In many ways I think this bullet should be shared between you and Lisa. Hola...
answer: I traced the PIN. I have an address for you. But I need to see you.

question: I show, you give me the information?
answer: Deal.

question: I'm looking for Rosanna Guerrero.
answer: Hombre en fuego. Man On Fire. That's what the papers have named you.

question: It's what you and Rosanna named me. Right?
answer: Sit, Creasy. Everything that happens from now on does so with my permission. Really. You won't find a better carne asada in all of Mexico. The last few days may represent the best police work of my life.

question: What do you want?
answer: The same thing as you. Except, my reach isn't as long as yours. My father was a policemen, did you know that?

question: I don't know shit about you.
answer: He was one of the original founders of 'Le Hermanidad' in the days when it represented good not evil. He was murdered. And now here I am. Trying to honor his memory. Hamstrung by bureaucracy and corruption. The organization that he began now protects criminals at the highest level where I would need a Presidential finding in order to expose it...or you. My family lives in Miami. Because of the death threats.

question: It's not worth it. Be with them instead.
answer: It galls me to watch you. You can do as much in days as I can in years. Men like the 'The Dreamer' are protected. Out of everyone's grasp it seems, but yours.

question: Are you going to arrest me or talk me to death?
answer: My country needs justice. Proper justice. Gunning men down in the street only feeds the violence. They need to be brought to trial. Dealt with properly. Then people will respect the law. When they see it works.

question: So you are going to talk me to death.
answer: You walk out and deal justice. You're what I wish I could be. The policemen who kills you, his family will have all they want.

question: Then I hope the one who gets me has got lots of kids. What do you want?
answer: I want to arrest you for murder! I want to shake your hand and reload your gun! I want to kill my pride and give you my blessing.

question: My deal is with Rosanna. I knew you guys were up to something. Are you two fucking?
answer: No, but I have to admit I thought about it.

question: Liar. Just tell me who the bank card belongs to. Name and address.
answer: You have no interest in making things easy, do you?

question: I'm not... easy.
answer: Percodan. I imagine you need handfuls by now. Account belongs to a woman we think is The Dreamer's girlfriend. Reina Rosas, who is 8 months pregnant. The plan is the girlfriend will lead you to the Boss. You'll lead me, and I'll arrest him. Agreed? Creasy... I'd have liked to have known you under different circumstances.

question: Behind the wheel of the Volkswagon, roars out chasing. Reina Rosas.
answer: Si.

question: How do you contact 'the Boss'?
answer: We page him and he calls back on this cell phone.

question: What is his name?
answer: Daniel.

question: Daniel what?
answer: Daniel Rosas Sanchez.

question: So you're married to him? And this looks remarkably like his brother. What is his name?
answer: Aurillio Rosas Sanchez.

question: Hello Daniel. I've got your family and I want to negotiate.
answer: Mr. Creasy. What do you want?

question: I want you.
answer: How much do you want?

question: It's non-negotiable.
answer: Two million U.S.... Three million U.S.?

question: Yeah.
answer: The most important thing in life is family. And there you are. You have my family. What do you want?

question: I want you.
answer: This is not possible. But in that house I have money. If I tell you where --

question: Yeah. Yes.
answer: Listen! I will give you a life for a life.

question: What do you mean?
answer: Her life for your life.

question: Whose life?
answer: The girl's. Pinta's.

question: You're a liar. Pinta's dead.
answer: I'm a businessman. A dead girl is worth nothing. She is alive.

question: I want proof of life. What did she call her bear?
answer: Creasy. She calls the bear 'Creasy Bear.'

question: Okay. Where? Lisa, don't hang up on me. Pinta is alive.
answer: I don't believe you.

question: I want you to get into your car now and meet me on the south end of the footbridge between Reforma and the freeway junction. In 45 minutes.
answer: You're lying. I don't believe you.

question: Then don't come.
answer: Creasy... Wait.
